This is a campaign by a coalition of over 90 legal, medical, community and human rights organisations calling on the Morrison government to release and resettle asylum seekers and refugees held in indefinite detention by World Refugee Day in June 2021. I certainly support this, and I call on all honourable members to support the Time for a Home campaign. Let's get everyone out of detention before World Refugee Day in June 2021. That would be the right thing to do as a country. It would show compassion, it would show integrity and it would show our respect for international law. It would be the right thing to do, and it would be a great example for other countries that often look to Australia to see how we behave and what we do. They might follow our lead.
Renewable Energy

Dr ALLEN (Higgins) (19:44): Australia is now officially in the midst of a major energy transition to a carbon neutral future. In the last three years alone, over $30 billion has been invested in Australia in renewable energy. The Clean Energy Regulator's latest Quarterly carbon market report estimates total delivered additional renewable capacity for this year is likely to match the record 6.3 gigawatts set in 2019. This is something we should all welcome and celebrate. It's the equivalent of 920,000 homes putting solar panels on their roof every year.

Affordable reliable energy will be critical to re-establishing a strong economy and supporting jobs as Australia recovers from the COVID pandemic. To get emissions down, new technologies will need to be nurtured, developed and embraced right across all sectors of our economy, but many are not yet matured to the point where we can rely on them to the exclusion of current market players. Take battery storage, for example. Even in South Australia, where renewables now provide nearly half of the state's electricity needs, gas is still required for practically all of the other half, with less than 0.4 per cent provided by batteries. Some argue battery technology is ready for prime time, but this is simply not true. Currently, two hours of storage is the maximum a battery can provide in the National Electricity Market and our biggest battery only has enough storage for one hour and 15 minutes.

Grid reliability requires firming power for much longer, for instance, overnight when the sun is no longer shining. Batteries are not yet capable of providing this energy for extended periods. They can add to gas's firming power, but they can't yet replace it. That's not to say that research investment in battery technology is not incredibly important. The federal technology investment roadmap regards long-duration energy storage technology as one of its five priorities in technologies for bridging to a carbon neutral future. This includes a stretch goal to drive the technology to a point at which it becomes more competitive than existing alternatives.

Our goal for long-duration energy storage, for instance using batteries, to be dispatched at under $100 per megawatt hour would enable firmed wind and solar power to be delivered at prices around or below today's average wholesale price. By optimising technology, science can help ensure our push into advanced manufacturing is fuelled by cheap and clean energy, but we need a transitionary approach to unleashing technology advances. That is why I recommend that all members of this House obtain a copy of the Technology investment roadmap: First low emissions technology statement 2020 and read it thoroughly. Harnessing Australia's ingenuity and supporting the uptake of new and innovative technology is key to this government's recently released low-emissions technology statement. This statement is the first time this country has delivered a concrete plan for emerging technologies with real action. This will pave the way for a zero net carbon future. Australia's first low-emissions technology statement has resulted from deliberations by the ministerial reference panel, chaired by Australia's Chief Scientist, Dr Alan Finkel AO, comprising of input from industry, private investment, government and research leaders. Recognising the panel's ongoing role in supporting future statements, it will be formalised and into a permanent technology investment advisory council, also chaired by Alan Finkel, who is stepping down after five years as a wonderful Chief Scientist of Australia.

Importantly, this technology plan has five stretch goals: clean hydrogen under $2 kilogram; technology storage, which is electricity from storage firming, under $100 per megawatt; low-carbon materials, which is low emissions steel production, under $900 per tonne; low-emissions aluminium under $2,700 per tonne; carbon capture and storage compression hub transport under $20 per tonne of carbon dioxide and soil carbon, which is to look at the measurement under $4 per hectare per year. By optimising technology, science can help ensure our push into advanced manufacturing is fuelled by clean and cheap energy, but we need a transitionary approach to unleashing technology advances. This is important now more than ever as we stretch to a post COVID world.
NAIDOC Week

Ms BURNEY (Barton) (19:49): The House understands that this week is NAIDOC Week. I particularly want to recognise your role, Mr Speaker, in making sure that the day was a success. I really appreciate that, as we all do. I want to particularly recognise the current chairs of the NAIDOC Committee nationally, Patricia Turner and John Paul Janke, but I also want to put very much on the record the enormous contribution of Dr Anne Martin and Ben Mitchell who are the past chairs of NAIDOC. I know Dr Martin spent 13 years in that position, and, through both Anne Martin and Ben Mitchell, we saw NAIDOC grow to be the amazing thing it is today, reaching across schools, local government areas, parliaments and all aspects of life. I want to particularly recognise their contribution. This year's theme, as we all know, is: 'Always Was, Always Will Be'. This is an interesting theme. Last year the theme was about recognition of women: 'Because of her, we can!' The theme this year was born out of the civil rights movement and aligned rights movement. The rest of that saying is: 'Always was, always will be Aboriginal land.'

I want to also say that NAIDOC is not a new thing in this nation. It has a long history. We saw that, in the 1920s, when Aboriginal rights groups boycotted Australia Day to protest against the status and poor treatment of Indigenous Australians. By the 1920s, the broader Australian public was clearly still largely ignorant of those boycotts. By Australia Day in 1938, the boycotts were finally noticed by the wider Australian public with thousands marching through the streets of Sydney. In the forties and fifties, a Day of Mourning became an annual event held on Sunday before Australia Day, and was known as Aborigines Day. In 1955, Aborigines Day was shifted to the first Sunday in July, which is what we now all celebrate. It became a day to also celebrate Aboriginal culture. In 1972, as an outcome of the 1967 referendum, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was formed, and, in 1974, the NAIDOC Committee was composed entirely of Aboriginal members for the first time.

The National Aborigines Day Observance Committee was formed in the early 1990s, and the title was expanded to include Torres Strait Islanders. The National NAIDOC Committee made key decisions on national celebrations each year and has representatives in most Australian states and territories. NAIDOC is now recognised by all of us as something to bring this country together, and I couldn't be prouder of that. The theme this year is: 'Always Was, Always Will Be'. First Nations peoples always have been, and always will be, spiritually and culturally connected to land. They have also occupied and cared for the land for over 65,000 years. One of the things I like to say is that this 65,000 years of story, of history, is not just the culture of First Australians. It is the story of this country, and, therefore, it is the history and culture of all Australians, and that's what's so wonderful about the NAIDOC Committee.

I conclude my remarks today by saying that I am extremely proud and touched by the care towards today on both sides of parliament. I am disappointed with the outcome of the flag debate in the other chamber, but it is what it is. Of course, we'll continue to prosecute that. The fact is that, if you go down Commonwealth Avenue, there are hundreds of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags. If you drive into Sydney airport, the flag flies there. If you drive past the New South Wales parliament, it flies outside. On occasion—not very often, but now and again—it actually flies off the Harbour Bridge. It is in front of schools; it is in front of the War Memorial. It is part of the Flags Act of Australia. As I said to 2GB this afternoon, flying the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flag is not meant to be divisive; it is something that we can all celebrate and embrace.

subdebateinfo.title: Tame, Ms Grace, Let Us Speak Campaign

p.span: Tame, Ms Grace
Let Us Speak Campaign

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (19:54): Earlier this year, in a speech to mark International Women's Day, I spoke about the brave work undertaken by a young Tasmanian woman, Grace Tame. Until recently, sexual assault survivors in my state were gagged by Tasmanian law, unable to share their experiences in the media. Grace was repeatedly abused by her former maths teacher Nicolaas Bester a decade ago. Her abuser has always been free to speak. But when Grace worked up the courage to tell her story, she was unable to do so due to the archaic law.

Grace joined forces with journalist, survivor and advocate Nina Funnell, and they created the Let Her Speak campaign, fighting to change the legislation. Grace had to take her case to the Supreme Court to be allowed to publicly self-identify as a rape survivor. Their fight saw the Tasmanian government amend the law earlier this year.

Just recently, I was thrilled to learn that Grace was named the 2021 Tasmanian Australian of the Year. In her acceptance speech, Grace discussed the journey from where she found herself 10 years ago, in a place of hopelessness, to standing on a public stage accepting such an esteemed award for her work. As Grace has told local media, her award is an important symbol for sexual assault survivors, stating:
It's hugely empowering for that community recognising and normalising the act of speaking out.
There's no shame in surviving. The shame sits at the feet of predators, of perpetrators of these crimes.

As a survivor myself, I can attest to the empowerment that comes from hearing the stories of other survivors, the hope for a future and the relief that the shame is not yours to carry. As Nina has said:
… I know firsthand that it can also be an important way of reclaiming a sense of ownership and control over an experience where one has felt fundamentally robbed of power and control.
Well done, Grace. We are so incredibly proud of you.

And, while these positive changes have been made in our state, it is distressing to hear what is happening in the Victorian parliament today, where the same type of draconian legislation is being considered, including whether to criminalise the naming of murdered sexual-assault victims. While I understand that the intent of the new reforms is to protect the needs and rights of victims-survivors of sexual violence, the proposed changes miss the mark, with perverse outcomes. For families of women murdered by acts of sexual violence—and I say 'women', as the victims are overwhelmingly female—the proposed changes include forcing grieving relatives to obtain a court order to speak. As Grace herself has commented, this bill fuels the stigma about sexual violence by attaching shame to the victim. Once again, Nina is leading the charge, fighting for the rights of victim-survivors and the families of victims to be heard. Nina, I know how hard it is. I see you and I applaud your grit and determination to drive forward.

I am absolutely dismayed to learn that the Victorian government did not even consult with any grieving relatives who would be affected by the bill before first introducing it last month. Jill Meagher's mother, Edith McKeon, has said: 'It's such a heartache on all of us who lost our precious ones. How dare they! We will fight it.'

And what happens to the legacy of survivors who do speak out? Sexual abuse survivor Ashleigh Rae Cooper has expressed her dismay that her life's work as an advocate may need to be removed. She says: 'I'll be lost to public memory. It will be as if I had never been able to speak at all.'

Let Her Speak has become Let Us Speak. Nina's call for the bill to be amended has also been backed by a coalition of media organisations who have jointly written to the government saying that the proposed gag is unsupported by law and will put Victoria at odds with mainland Australia as an outlier jurisdiction.

I stand with Grace and Nina and with all survivors, victims and their families, and I urge the Victorian government to reconsider. We will keep fighting for our voices to be heard. Let us speak. Remember our names. We have earned that right.
Question agreed to.
NOTICES
The following notices were given:
Mr Littleproud: To present a Bill for an Act to amend the Export Control Act 2020, and for related purposes. (Export Control Amendment (Miscellaneous Measures) Bill 2020)

Mr Tehan: To present a Bill for an Act to amend the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000, and for related purposes. (Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment (Refunds of Charges and Other Measures) Bill 2020)
Mr Hill: To present a Bill for an Act to amend the Migration Act 1958, and for related purposes. (Migration Amendment (Common Sense Partner Visa) Bill 2020)

Mr Wilkie: To present a Bill for an Act to amend the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009, and for related purposes. (National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2020)
Ms Coker: To move—That this House:
(1) notes:
(a) that the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) is currently undergoing its second ten-yearly statutory review;
(b) the findings from the interim report of the Samuel Review, including that:
(i) the environment and our iconic places are in decline and under increasing threat;
(ii) more than 10 per cent of Australia's land mammals are now extinct and a further 21 per cent are threatened and declining;
(iii) land-use change, habitat loss and degradation, feral animals and invasive plant species place significant pressures on our environment; and
(iv) our oceans face significant current and future threats from climate change and human activity; and
(2) calls on the Government to:
(a) abandon its attempt to rehash Prime Minister Abbott's failed amendments to the EPBC Act;
(b) listen to environment and industry experts' calls to prioritise robust environmental reform;
(c) effectively protect environmental matters that are important for the nation;
(d) improve our environment for current and future generations; and
(e) provide more certainty for jobs and investment.
Dr Freelander: To move—That this House:
(1) acknowledges its concerns about the inequitable access to stroke treatment for Australians living in rural and regional areas; and

(2) notes its support for a national approach to ensuring access to best practice treatment for people experiencing stroke through the establishment of a national mechanical thrombectomy advisory committee.
Dr Haines: To move—That this House:
(1) agrees that effective politics requires constructive debate and consensus building on policy challenges and roadblocks that, if left unresolved, undermine the national interest;
(2) commends the Menzies-Calwell club for facilitating consensus-driven, cross-parliamentary policy discussions that do not regress into ineffectual, politically polarised rhetoric;

(3) reaffirms that establishing a robust federal integrity commission during this parliament well before the next election is essential to arresting the declining public trust in institutions and restoring Australians' faith in the democratic system;
(4) notes that, according to the Beechworth Principles and the motion agreed to by the Senate on 9 November 2020, a federal integrity commission must have:
(a) broad jurisdiction to investigate corrupt conduct within the public sector;
(b) common rules for all public officials;
(c) strong investigative powers and procedural fairness safeguards;
(d) an ability to hold public hearings when in the public interest;
(e) direct avenues for public referrals and an ability to commence investigations independently based on those referrals;
(f) strong whistleblower protections;
(g) adequate and secure funding to be able to fulfil its purpose; and
(h) oversight by a multi-party parliamentary committee, including of the appointment of commissioners, and an independent parliamentary inspector to ensure accountability to the people; and

(5) encourages Members of Parliament to debate the Australian Federal Integrity Commission Bill 2020 and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Standards Bill 2020 as a robust consensus package that all parliamentarians can engage with, in good faith, as a non-aligned private member's bill that answers the strong call from the Australian public for a robust federal integrity commission.
Mr Giles: To move—That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) it has been seven years since New Zealand offered hope to those refugees in Papua New Guinea and Nauru to resettle them in New Zealand; and

(b) more than 65,000 Australians have signed a petition organised by Amnesty International Australia with Craig Foster and Sonny Bill Williams urging the Government to accept the New Zealand Government's generous offer to resettle those refugees; and
(2) calls on the Government to accept the New Zealand offer to resettle refugees.
Mr T. R. Wilson: To move—That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) Tuesday 1 December 2020 is World AIDS Day, an annual day to acknowledge those we have lost to AIDS related conditions and those who are living with HIV;
(b) the theme for World AIDS Day 2020 is 'Now More Than Ever';
(c) stigma associated with HIV acts as a barrier to treatment and prevention;
(d) action is needed to address rising HIV transmission among First Nations, trans and gender diverse people, and other emerging high-risk population groups;
(e) gay and bisexual men continue to bear the burden of Australia's HIV epidemic and ongoing health education and awareness among this population group is needed; and
(f) further bipartisan political action and leadership is required to meet our national target of ending HIV transmission in Australia; and
(2) recognises and acknowledges the:
(a) journey that people have made through their diagnosis, treatment and experiences of living with HIV;

(b) tremendous efforts of peer educators, healthcare professionals, researchers and scientists in developing treatment and prevention regimes that have improved the lives of people living with HIV and prevented a generalised epidemic in Australia;
(c) success of a bipartisan approach in Australia's health response; and
(d) tireless community advocates, civil society organisations and support groups that actively tackle stigma associated with HIV.
Mr Simmonds: To move—That this House:

(1) recognises that the Government has established the Australian Centre to Counter Child Exploitation (ACCCE) as the frontline defence in the Government's fight to protect children from predators online, in Australia and across the world;
(2) acknowledges that:

(a) ACCCE brings together the specialist expertise and skills from government agencies, law enforcement and advocacy groups, in a central hub, to investigate cases of child exploitation and to implement prevention strategies;

(b) in the period 1 July 2019 to 30 June 2020, the ACCCE received more than 21,000 incoming reports of child exploitation, compared with 14,000 in 2018-2019—from this, 134 children were removed from harm; and
(c) recent operations by the ACCCE removed 16 children in Australia from harm and arrested 44 offenders with 350 charges collectively;
(3) welcomes the Government's significant investment in establishing the ACCCE, with $68.6 million committed over four years to further the crucial work they do to protect children;

(4) notes the recent opening of the new purpose-built facility and thanks all the Australian Federal Police and state police officers for their selfless work in tracking and apprehending predators; and
(5) commits to the ongoing safety of all Australian children, both online and in our communities, by continuing the Government's recent investment in anti-exploitation measures.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Vamvakinou)
took the chair at 12:15.
BILLS
Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2020-2021
Consideration in Detail
Proposed expenditure, $3,690,012,000

Mr HUNT (Flinders—Minister for Health and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service and Cabinet) (12:15): This has been the hardest of years for Australia. So this budget was framed around two principles. One is implementing those measures necessary to continue to keep Australians safe from the pandemic, whilst also provisioning for the services required to advance and build on that which we have done across the pillars of the Long Term National Health Plan.

In terms of COVID-19, we see again today, from the reports that I have, that there are no known cases in the community. There are two jurisdictions still to come in but, on the six that we have, there are zero cases. That builds on what we've done in recent days and the success Australians have had by global comparison, where we see now over 50 million cases and 1¼ million lives lost—and those are only the official figures. To that end, the Australian government, through this budget, has now committed $18.5 million in the fight against the pandemic.

Most recently, we have completed the additional acquisitions of two new vaccines, the Novavax vaccine for 40 million units and the Pfizer vaccine for 10 million units—an innovative mRNA vaccine. The world has never had an mRNA vaccine for any condition at any time ever before. The news overnight on the results was heartening for Australians. I spoke with the Australian CEO this morning, and that data is promising. There's more to be done—we welcome it and will consider it cautiously—but we are on track to deliver a vaccine for Australians during the first quarter of 2021.

In addition to that, the $18.5 billion includes funding for our containment process, whether that is dealing with the consequences of our international border closures, which have saved lives, or our testing regime, which now sees over 9.1 million tests conducted. It's important to remember at the time when the world suffered mass shortages in testing equipment, Australia maintained, continued and expanded our testing regime and, similarly, the tracing program and then the distancing regime.

In particular, though, as well as flattening the curve, we also built the base of our system in Australia, with now over 38 million telehealth consultations with the mental health investment of over half a billion dollars, the investment in aged care of over $1.6 billion. Even though we have seen agonising losses, the Medical Journal of Australia tells us that 16,000 lives have been saved in Australia through our actions as a nation. Then, of course, there is the work in our hospitals, where we've had the public hospitals agreement and the private hospitals agreement and the development of a 7,500 respirator or ventilator capacity in Australia.

That brings me to the budget as we move forward—a budget of $115 billion. If you look at the key pillars of the Australian Long Term National Health Plan, there is an investment in Medicare which sees a growth of $6 billion in Medicare investment. This sees the expansion of new treatments and new programs through Medicare. Importantly, we also see that we have gone from $19 billion to $29 billion in Medicare investment in our time. We then moved forward from there to what we've done in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, with $41 billion for new medicines such as Lynparza being provisioned so we never again have the situation we faced in 2011, where the then government refused to list medicines, on the basis of fiscal circumstances rather than on the basis of medical advice. Then we moved forward to what we've been able to do in relation to hospitals, with $133 billion, a $33 billion increase, over the course of the next five-year agreement. In mental health there is an additional $500 million over the course of the coming budget. In medical research what we see is that there's $6.6 billion available. In aged care we have over the forward estimates approximately $25 billion, $26 billion, $27 billion and $28 billion. All of those are about saving lives and protecting lives.

Ms COLLINS (Franklin) (12:20): Unfortunately, what we've seen during this COVID crisis here in Australia is that, whilst there have been many successes—and I do want to congratulate particularly some of the state premiers on some of the work that they have done around that battle, working bipartisan with the government to ensure that Australians are protected—sadly for many Australians this has been a very difficult period, particularly for those 685 families who lost loved ones during the COVID-19 outbreaks in residential aged care and aged care generally. We on this side and those on the other side of the House pass our condolences on to the family and friends of those loved ones.

The real tragedy of course is that aged care was in crisis before COVID. That is the truth of it. Those on the opposite side have been in government for eight years. It has been on their watch that we have seen the aged-care system in Australia deteriorate to the point where they had to call a royal commission into aged care in Australia, essentially calling a royal commission into themselves. That is what we saw prior to COVID-19. What we didn't see in this budget that we should have seen were some measures to actually address what was happening in residential aged care with the COVID outbreaks. We heard from the royal commission that the government didn't do enough. That's what we heard from the royal commission. The royal commissioners thought that it was so serious what had happened in residential aged care with COVID prior to outbreaks in Victoria and the community but also after outbreaks in New South Wales. We had reports on outbreaks in New South Wales about what had happened in Dorothy Henderson Lodge and residential aged-care facilities in New South Wales. The government seemed to always respond too slowly and by not doing enough. That was what happened during the outbreaks in residential aged care right across the country no matter where they happened.

To have Professor Murphy say that perhaps if they had done something sooner in terms of compulsory masks in residential aged-care centres we could have saved lives is an admission from the government that perhaps they could and should have done more sooner. To have them say that aged-care response centres should have been set up sooner or could have been set up sooner, and that if we had done that we could have saved lives, shows that the government didn't do enough soon enough. Sadly there are 685 families grieving because of what we've seen in residential aged care.

This is a terrible tragedy for our country, where we are No. 4 in the world when it comes to that disproportionate outbreak and what we've seen with those deaths in residential aged care. It is shocking that we did not see more from the government in relation to that in this budget. I think the concern of many Australians is that they don't trust this government to respond properly to its own royal commission into aged care, because of course they didn't with the interim report. The very first recommendation was to fix the home-care waiting list. We now have over 102,000 older Australians waiting for home care in Australia. There are over 100,000 who have been waiting for two years. The mean wait time for someone on a level 4 package is three years. In the announcement in the budget of the 23,000 packages, the question to the minister in the government is: why so few of them were level 4 packages, the ones people really need to stay at home? Why were so few of them for that level, where the demand is so high? We know that that is the difference between somebody going into residential aged care or staying at home with the support of their family and their loved ones like they want to. The government could have made a difference on budget night. It should've made a difference. It should've listened to its own royal commission.

Then we had the COVID report. There are six recommendations before the government. The royal commissioners have asked the government to respond to the parliament by December at the very latest about what happened with COVID and residential aged care. Well, here we are. We have this sitting week and one more sitting day before the government has to respond to that report. I hope the government does seriously respond to that when it comes to the parliament, because I haven't seen infection control officers, or infection control trained staff in every residential aged-care facility like the report recommends. I haven't seen the increased numbers of staff in terms of visitation in residential aged-care facilities to make sure that those older Australians that have been disconnected from their families can have visitors again. I haven't seen that in every aged-care facility around the country. The government didn't do enough and it didn't do it soon enough.

Mr COULTON (Parkes—Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government) (12:25): As everyone in this place knows the last year has been particularly difficult for Australians with the COVID pandemic. Regional Australia has responded very well with the policies this government has put in: with the respiratory clinics, a large number of those are in regional Australia; with telehealth, which was basically already operating in some of the more remote parts of regional Australia. We've been able to bring that across to the whole country, which has been a great tool to keep people safe and to keep them connected to their doctors.

There's an extra $57 million to CareFlight and the Royal Flying Doctor Service to have that extra capacity of retrieval should we need it, but thankfully the level of infection has been quite low in the regions and the ones that we've had have been managed incredibly well. I think the response of the workforce—the nurses, the doctors, the paramedics—right across regional Australia, and the local community, to this pandemic has been admirable. With the response we saw in Shepparton a few weeks ago, where 6,000 people were tested over a couple of days, what could've been a major disaster turned out to be just a couple of infections.

The upshot of this is that regional Australia has come through this in a great light. There's unprecedented interest in people wanting to relocate to live and work in regional Australia, and that reinforces the point that we need to have adequate health services in the regions. With GPs alone over the last decade the ratio of doctors coming through the system to population has nearly tripled, but the maldistribution means that many of those GPs are still maintaining a residency in larger centres and in capital cities. The focus of the government has been to create an environment where the workforce—medical professionals—are looking to go and work in the regions. So I was really pleased that in the budget we funded some trial sites across southern and western New South Wales looking at various models to deliver health. These aren't government models. These are supporting models that have come up from the local community, the state government through their local health district, local GPs and across those areas. We'll be watching very closely to see what can happen so that we can replicate that in other states around the country.

I'm particularly interested in the Murrumbidgee model, which is a partnership between the federal government, through the PHN, and the local health district and local health professionals. It's creating a model for generalist registrars with secure employment over a period of time, with support from senior practitioners, with a balance of work and life so that a lot of the barriers that were not encouraging people to go to regional areas have been removed. We have supported the multidisciplinary training across the country, putting more funds into the university departments of rural health to train doctors, allied health professionals and nurses in regional Australia where they are really needed.

The appointment of the new Rural Health Commissioner, Professor Stewart, is another step forward in the rollout of looking at better ways of delivering health services into the region. Dr Stewart has hit the ground running. She is soon to be joined by two assistant commissioners, who will have experience in allied health and nursing. One of those people will be an Indigenous person, with experience in Indigenous health. It is about changing the dynamic so that going to work in regional Australia is a career-enhancing move. The communities that need that support value their local health professionals. We're encouraging our younger people to come through with the continuation of our rural medical schools. The first one starts in Orange next year, with enrolments— (Time expired)

Ms RISHWORTH (Kingston) (12:30): Since well before this pandemic started, a generation of young Australians have harboured growing unease about their future, and the impact of this crisis has only served to exacerbate these concerns. Young Australians are seeing in real time the rise in unemployment, underemployment, job insecurity, wage stagnation, barriers to education and training, disruption to education and training, difficulty in transitioning from study to work and psychological distress, and they are seeing the environment in decline. They've seen the opportunities for success and fulfilment that previous generations enjoyed become out of reach for them, and they feel cut off from the decision-making process. To the great dismay of young people in Australia, the Morrison government seem to have squibbed their opportunity to offer real hope.

Some people might be wondering why I am talking about youth in this portfolio. That's my first question to the minister: why is the portfolio for youth sitting in the Health portfolio? The second question for the minister is: can you confirm that the government has allocated no ongoing funding to the Youth portfolio beyond this December? My next question is: can you confirm that the only shred of youth-specific government infrastructure, the Youth Taskforce, will be disbanded at the end of this year? Is the government disbanding the Youth Taskforce because young Australians are not going to have any more problems after this year? Is that the government's assumption?

I understand that the government has cut this money—has hollowed out the Youth portfolio—but the one thing that could be delivered in December is a policy framework report. Can the government confirm that this will have recommendations or will set goals? The one job of the Youth Taskforce is to provide a policy framework, but in Senate estimates the officials at the table could not confirm whether or not there would be any recommendations or any goals set. If goals are going to be set, given that there was no money in the budget, will the minister confirm that the government will find money in the budget to implement the recommendations and goals?

Could the minister also explain why the short-lived Youth Taskforce sits under preventative health and chronic disease support in the Health portfolio? Does this mean that the government doesn't take it seriously? That's certainly how it seems to me. Also, can the minister confirm what research it's done to look at the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic recession on young Australians? We haven't been able to get confirmation beyond potentially some focus groups being done by non-government organisations. I'd like to know what research the bureaucracy has done so that it can understand what is happening to young people.

My other question is: was anyone in the youth area consulted on the JobMaker credit? The Minister for Youth and Sport confirmed in Senate estimates that he was not consulted. I'd like to know if anyone else in the Department of Health, given that it is the department that is meant to represent young people in this government, was consulted on the JobMaker hiring credit.
Mr Hunt: I was.

Ms RISHWORTH: Well, I'm really pleased that you were. It's a pity the minister for youth wasn't. And now that the minister has confirmed that, I'd love to know what consultation he had with young people to see if this was their view, if this was their solution, because young people are telling me they haven't had much interaction with the government.

Finally, in August, the Prime Minister said to young Australians at the Youth Futures Summit, 'I'm counting on you, you're counting on me, so let's make a deal.' I wonder where he got that from. 'Let's live up to that promise to help each other.' The government axed the Youth Taskforce, there is no ongoing funding and no plans to coordinate youth issues, and they may not have recommendations or goals. This doesn't sound like a very good deal for young Australians. Young Australians have played their part in the pandemic. Why is the government giving such a dud deal to young Australians? Why is the government not properly consulting with young Australians about their response? Why is the government not funding proper responses for young Australians? And why is the government ignoring young Australians?

Dr ALLEN (Higgins) (12:35): What a wonderful opportunity the member opposite me has just provided to talk about young Australians. I think members on the other side of the bench would really be aware that mental health issues affect the young disproportionately. We unfortunately know that, as the young struggle with identity issues or face changes through their life, mental health issues disproportionately affect them. So I am delighted that this government is taking very strong steps to deal with issues of mental health, particularly for our young, but also youth suicide. We understand how important this is. As a doctor, I'm incredibly passionate about better health outcomes for all Australians, but of course especially for the young. Being a mother of four young adults, I am constantly being reminded of how important their mental health is and the mental health of, indeed, their entire generation. So I am very pleased that, in the budget, the Morrison government has committed such a significant amount to mental health and suicide prevention. But, more than that, the government has been on the front foot when it comes to mental health and suicide prevention, particularly through the COVID pandemic. It has a very keen understanding of how important it is to provide more services for those who seek and need to access mental health services. This is particularly true with regard to telehealth. The telehealth Medicare item number has been an astounding success. I'd like to extend the deep gratitude of the constituents of my electorate to the Minister for Health, Greg Hunt, for the work that he has done with telehealth. He has provided support for not just general health but also mental health.

We have been doing more than any other previous government to safeguard the mental health of all Australians, with funding expected to reach $5.7 billion this year. This is all within a framework which the Minister for Health has led with the Fifth National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Plan, which commenced in 2017. So there has been a clear and long-term strategic understanding that prevention, better access and better service provision are central to improving the mental health of not just young Australians but all Australians. Important in this is the provision of frontline services to meet the specific needs of local communities, because we know that mental health is a local community issue. You need to provide support in a localised and community orientated way. This is being done by the Morrison government through the provision of $1.6 billion in our primary health networks. Many people don't really know much about the primary health networks. They are, in my view, the jewel in the crown for primary health services across Australia. There are 31 primary health networks. I would like to give a shout-out to Elizabeth Deveny, who is the CEO of the South Eastern Melbourne Primary Health Network. She is an amazing CEO of a very important health network that has provided testing and PPE to local GPs throughout the south-east. It has been an incredibly important relationship that she has had with her local GPs.

There are many achievements that I can speak to, but unfortunately I only have 1½ minutes left, so I can't go through all the investment in mental health that this government has provided, but I'd like to point out just a few. These include the implementation of the National Support for Child and Youth Mental Health Program, which provides $133 million over five years for Emerging Minds and Beyond Blue to improve mental health outcomes for children and young people. I am a paediatrician, and I note the member for Macarthur in the chamber, who also has a keen interest in children and paediatrics and the minds of the young. This is all part of the Beyond Blue mental health in education initiative Be You to provide young Australians with additional support in school. That is to the tune of $98 million. There was also the launch of Head to Health in 2017, the government's mental health gateway, offering quality digital mental health resources. I know that that's been taken up very well right across Australia.

In the most recent budget, there has been significant additional funding for mental health supports, including new centres to treat residential eating disorders, the most deadly kind of psychiatric disorder, which affects disproportionately young people, unfortunately; eight community mental health hubs; importantly, a perinatal mental health program; and mental health in the workplace. Minister, could you explain how the government is also working on improvements—because we always need to do better—to the mental health system as a whole through several key reviews and strategic priorities?

Ms McBRIDE (Dobell) (12:41): This year has been tough for so many Australians. We've faced the Black Summer bushfires, floods and, of course, the virus. More than at any other time in recent decades, Australians have relied on mental health support to help them through this year. Only on the way into the House this morning, I heard from a father who had lost his son due to mental health issues. Since March, Beyond Blue have seen an increase in demand for counselling services of between 30 and 40 per cent each month, peaking at the height of the pandemic in May. ReachOut saw a 48 per cent increase in its youth, parent and school services from March to May, with more than 184,000 extra people accessing support, and most seeking assistance due to COVID-19.

Labor has been constructive and has offered bipartisan support throughout the government's response to the pandemic. We've welcomed the government's $74 million for preventative health measures and the $48.1 million for the National Mental Health and Wellbeing Pandemic Response Plan. We were relieved, as were so many Australians, particularly in regional and remote Australia, when the government increased the number of telehealth services from 10 to 20 across Australia, and we're pleased to see this change reflected in the budget.

However, there is a gap and lag between announcements and delivery, and this is hurting Australians. Last year I raised with the minister the National Children's Mental Health and Wellbeing Strategy announced in August 2019. We supported the strategy then and still do today. It is well established that half of all mental health conditions experienced across our life spans have started by the age of 14. This is why I was disappointed to hear in Senate estimates that the strategy will not be finalised until at least June next year, nearly two years after the minister's announcement. A draft strategy is due this month. My question to the minister is: has the minister received a draft yet? If not, does the minister expect to see the strategy this month? During a global pandemic, a national coordinated approach to children's mental health is now even more urgent.

I turn now to the Productivity Commission report into mental health, which presents an opportunity to address the growing mental health challenges faced by all Australians. I want to acknowledge all of those individuals, organisations and advocates in the sector who have contributed by making submissions through this process. Before coming to this place, I worked as a pharmacist, for much of the time in acute adult mental health inpatient units. Every day I saw firsthand the circumstances of people's lives that led to mental health crisis, emergency and acute admission. I was part of a team stretched and at times buckling under the strain of growing demand and scarce resources. Minister, I'm not sure if you know what it feels like to be part of a team where you see someone who needs help, and you know that help should be available, but in a wealthy country like Australia we can't provide it. Minister, why do we have this narrowcast view of health which means that vulnerable people in acute crisis, particularly in regional and remote Australia, cannot get the help they need when they need it? Teams are under extraordinary strain, and people are discharged to the circumstances that made them sick. I've seen people discharged to caravan parks and to caves. Why, in a wealthy country like Australia, in the middle of a pandemic, is the only safe place for someone sometimes a public hospital bed? It's just not right. The Productivity Commission report gives the chance to address the issues at the cause—the underlying problems of unemployment, education, housing, the burden of which is carried disproportionately by those in our society who have the least. Where you are born, live and grow up in Australia matters.

The terms of reference for the inquiry into mental health were released in November 2018, nearly two years ago. The PC's interim report into mental health was released in October last year. The final report has been sitting with the government for five months. Professor Ian Hickie of the Brain and Mind Centre said before the budget that it was essential the government release the report 'because we need a large, systemic and informed response in the October budget'. That opportunity has now been missed. Instead, the government handed down its budget last month and missed the opportunity to respond to the PC report on mental health. A response now appears unlikely before the next budget. If that is the case, it will be 2½ years between it being announced and any action or response by this government. Minister, when will the report be released, and what process is in place for consultation to take place before the government's response? In Senate estimates we heard reports suggesting that health officials were unsure whether they had received the final version of the report. It's been with the government since June. Minister, does the health department have the final version of the report, and who else has been involved in this process?
I want to finish by saying: this is urgent; it matters. I know you are genuine and you care. What we now need to see is action.

Mr CONAGHAN (Cowper) (12:46): I rise today to speak on the challenges that exist for residents in my electorate of Cowper in accessing doctors, specialists and health professionals. Our story in Cowper is not new; indeed, it shares similarities with many other rural and regional electorates across our nation. But, before I continue, I would like to thank the Minister for Health and the Minister for Regional Health for their quick response to assist my electorate of Cowper during the Black Summer bushfires. The ministers acted swiftly to put in place procedures to allow both restricted and unrestricted doctors and allied health professionals to work in bushfire affected areas like ours. This meant my community had extra support at a time when we needed it most.

We are fortunate in this country to have a first-class healthcare system. It's a system that is the envy of many nations across the world. You only need to look at the Morrison-McCormack government's track record at managing COVID-19 and ensuring safe and ongoing access to medical and mental health assistance, through telehealth and voice and video counselling, to appreciate the standard of health care we enjoy. Whilst this is so, our healthcare system still has many challenges impacting access for rural and regional Australians.

I would like to paint a picture of my electorate. Our number of retiree-age citizens is over 41,000, one of the largest populations of this age group in Australia. If you look at the median age of someone residing in Cowper, you'll see that it's 47, rather than the national average of 38. Our region also supports over 9,000 recipients on a disability support pension—again, one of the largest numbers for an electorate in our country. We have a significant number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in Cowper, who more commonly experience chronic disease such as respiratory disease, cardiovascular disease and diabetes, and we have pockets of socioeconomically disadvantaged Australians who are living below the poverty line. This is often linked to poorer health outcomes and is no doubt a contributing factor to the 2017-18 NSW Health data released in July this year and canvassed in the media this week. The data revealed that the Nambucca Valley came in at fifth place for the most avoidable deaths, at 130.3 deaths per 100,000 and Kempsey was not far behind, with 126.9 avoidable deaths per 100,000 people.

I believe it's this demographic mix within Cowper that has naturally placed more pressure on the medical services available and the healthcare workforce in my region. Patients are more likely to have complex or chronic conditions, requiring more regular consultations, more complex treatment and the coordination of specialist care requirements. We have dedicated health professional services in our region; however, the complexity and demand on access are placing the entire system under pressure, under the previous workforce model. Constituents I speak with often report to me that they experience limited availability of general practice doctors, particularly bulk-billing doctors, long wait times, a lack of choice for specialists and a lack of community transport options to access medical specialists in Coffs Harbour or Port Macquarie, often facing longer travel times to Sydney or Brisbane. Of equal concern is the welfare of our healthcare professionals. They have a commitment to providing quality care to their communities, and sometimes the system's failing causes a toll on their own health and wellbeing.

I must acknowledge the work that the Minister for Health and the Minister for Regional Health have been doing to address this complex issue that impacts rural and regional health, and the great body of work that has been done to reform the sector and implement programs such as implementing the distribution priority area system, implementing the rural generalist pathway and creating the National Rural Health Commissioner. So I would like to ask the Minister for Health and the Minister for Regional Health, can you please outline how the government's investment in this year's budget will improve access to doctors, specialists and health-care professionals in regional Australia? Is the government trialling different approaches to creating a sustainable workforce and building the rural training pipeline? And how will this benefit local communities living in rural and regional Australia, like citizens of Cowper?

Ms KEARNEY (Cooper) (12:50): I don't think anyone in Australia would disagree with me when I say that the biggest policy failing during the COVID-19 pandemic has been in residential aged care. We watched a tragedy unfold before our very eyes. As the member for Franklin told us, nearly 700 people have died of COVID in aged-care facilities. Many died undignified deaths, unable to say goodbye to loved ones, incoherent, dehydrated and confused. Families are traumatised, with a lifetime of good memories tainted by a bad death.

Yet this budget contains very little for residential aged care. Their response is astounding. This government's response was to blame-shift, disgracefully trying to sidestep accountability. At a time when we should have all been in it together, they wanted to step aside. I would like to say I'm surprised, but I'm not—because the government's aged-care response has been led by an incompetent minister who will be remembered for turning his back on Senator Wong as she tried to hold him to account for his government's failings.

Our aged-care system is broken. It was broken before the COVID pandemic, but the pandemic has shone a light through the cracks. Despite the buck-passing by this government, trying to throw Victoria, my state, under the bus, we all know who is responsible for aged care: the federal government. The federal government is responsible. They have failed to regulate and to ensure that all aged-care facilities had enough staff, the right mix of nurses and carers and adequate protection—PPE equipment. The federal government and some providers failed to provide workers with a secure job or decent pay, so infection spread as workers had to move across several facilities. There was, I admit, a feeble attempt to halt this, but many providers who tried to do the right thing by their staff said that the efforts were weak. They failed to heed the warning calls about how to control a COVID outbreak, and there were so many. The counsel assisting the aged care royal commission, when investigating the outbreaks in Newmarch House and Dorothy Henderson Lodge, asked, 'What did the Commonwealth do to ensure the lessons of the two outbreaks were learned?' The answer: not enough. The Prime Minister's plan was nothing more than guidelines offered up by an uninterested minister who never acted with urgency, who infamously said that the portfolio should only take up about a day a week of his time as minister. Well, that day a week was not very productive. His so-called plan failed. It's a nonsense to say otherwise—actually, it's an insult to say otherwise.

The title of the royal commission's interim report was Neglect. Neglect is not a word that anyone relying on the aged-care system wants to hear. Neglect outlines a litany of long-term, systemic problems that this government has failed to fix during its seven-year term. As a former nurse and head of the nurses union, I have spent a large part of my career fighting for a better aged-care system, a system that offers residents of aged-care facilities the dignity they deserve in their latter years. I've been saying for decades that we need regulated staffing levels, a proper skill mix of professionals, better pay and training for staff, decent jobs, decent shifts that give people a living. We need to make sure that aged-care providers are accountable for the government funding they receive, so we know that it's being spent on quality care and not just on maximising profits at the expense of good care, at the expense of quality nursing, at the expense of quality equipment and of a decent living.

Labor have said enough is enough. We've announced a plan for aged care, which includes minimum staffing levels in residential aged care, reducing the homecare package waiting list, and ensuring transparency and accountability of funding to support high-quality care. There is no point in giving the sector millions and millions of extra dollars if there's no accountability for how that is spent. Given that the government has failed residential aged care, I ask: is the government ready to accept the royal commission's recommendations when they're handed down in February? Will it act on those recommendations? Is it getting ready for a systematic overhaul of the sector? Judging by the scanty amount in the budget commitment, I suspect not. I suspect it doesn't care for the dignity and safety of our elderly at all.

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (12:55): During my first speech, I referenced George Bass, the namesake of the electorate that I represent. George Bass was a surgeon and a reminder, as I outlined in my speech, of how vital the provision of health services is in the northern Tasmanian community. Almost 18 months later, my fight for better health services for the electorate continues. There continues to be considerable funding for our public hospital services across the state, with the federal government contributing $445.5 million in the 2019-20 financial year, which is an increase from the $294.1 million investment in the 2012-13 budget. But in a state with an ageing population and overrepresented in chronic disease statistics, there are complex challenges that surround our public system. Under federal minister Greg Hunt and state minister Sarah Courtney, much progress has been made, including the recent announcement of $45 million for Minister Courtney to address elective surgery waiting lists.

But a significant focus for me, since being elected, has been improving access for my community to GP services. There are many issues in this space; however, the ability to recruit and retain general practitioners is paramount. From Lilydale to Prospect, Summerhill and Mowbray, our community is lucky to have a number of general practices dedicated to servicing people in their communities, many with complex needs and high rates of socioeconomic disadvantage, but they are left short due to lack of access and GP shortages. The subject of access and GP shortages is one that I have been raising for over a year now with Minister Hunt and Minister Coulton. And whilst I greatly appreciate the time they have taken to work with me on the challenges the northern Tasmanian community faces, there is still a concern around the application of the Modified Monash Model classification, and that it is having an adverse effect on these practices, including their ability to recruit and retain great doctors.

The introduction of telehealth earlier this year has had a significantly positive impact on the community, and for practices in the region, particularly in suburbs where disadvantage exists, such as the northern suburbs. A local resident who is involved in several community organisations in the area told me it's difficult to access health care for various reasons, so telehealth has been a godsend, particularly for those who can't travel, and it's free, which is very attractive to our area. The importance of the investment in this area cannot be understated, and I'm pleased that the service will continue. But, aside from the continuation of telehealth, which is welcome, can the minister outline whether there are any plans to effectively address the concerns that I've mentioned to ensure greater health services can be delivered to northern Tasmanians, particularly those in low-socioeconomic areas?

One health area where we're continuing to make strides is in the mental health sector, with over $45 million in funding provided to our PHN to plan and commission regionally appropriate mental health and suicide prevention services. A further $5 million has been provided for a national suicide prevention trial site in the state, and an additional $10 million to support the development of a community based residential eating disorder treatment centre in Hobart. This is on top of the significant funding provided to local headspace centres across the state, including the newly opened full service headspace in Devonport.

I was thrilled to secure the funding for an adult mental health hub to be located in Launceston, in my electorate of Bass. From discussions with allied health workers, general practitioners and members of the community I speak with on the ground, there is a need to provide additional mental health services to meet the demand and fill the gaps that exist within the current service delivery. Getting the hub up and running is a priority of mine, and, despite the limitations that we have seen from COVID-19, I know that much work has been happening behind the scenes with the government and the PHN working collaboratively to ensure what is delivered will meet the needs of our community. Can the minister please provide an update as to the progress of this important project?

Dr FREELANDER (Macarthur) (12:59): I was a pretty lucky young doctor. I started my medical career at the time of Gough Whitlam and free university fees, and I subsequently opened my private paediatric practice at the time of Medicare, brought in by the Hawke and Keating government. The reason it was so important to have a universal healthcare insurance scheme was that medical costs were the commonest cause of bankruptcy in Australia. People just couldn't afford to get adequate care, and Medicare was resoundingly popular because what it did was introduce this concept of the community paying for what was an essential service for everyone. It was very popular and did very well.

But the simple truth now is that we are approaching a similar watershed time. People are now being faced with huge gap costs to pay for medical care. There has been an effective collapse of the public hospital outpatient system. There's a huge discrepancy in life expectancy between those living in inner metropolitan areas and those living in rural, regional and remote areas. Just as an example, people living in the inner city of Sydney have an average life expectancy in the mid-80s for males. If that is transcribed to outer regional areas, it's 67. So there is almost 20 years difference. It's a tragedy.

There has also been an extreme polarisation of medical workforces in our communities—from inner metropolitan to outer metropolitan, rural and regional areas—and that's not being addressed. I see it every day. Just as an example, on Friday of last week I was contacted by a constituent, who doesn't want to be named, but I'll just call him Ray. Ray is a self-funded retiree. He required a prostatectomy for prostate cancer. He had been paying insurance all his married life. He's a guy in his late 70s. He was treated by a very good local surgeon in a private hospital and had all of the treatment. He contacted me not by way of complaint but just to explain that the Medicare rebate for his surgery was $2,200. The cost of the surgery billed by the surgeon was over $13,000. He was also faced with over $1,000 in extra gap fees to pay for the anaesthetist and to pay for a number of other hospital and rehabilitation fees for his surgery. Now, the reason that he contacted me is that he thought it was very unfair that he'd paid his private health insurance all his married life—over 50 years—yet was now faced with this huge bill of $15,000 to have surgery. But he did also note that, if he'd wanted to have his surgery done in the public hospital, he would have been faced with a waiting period of some months. So, really, this huge discrepancy is affecting people every day.

People are also being faced with large payments to see specialists. In my particular electorate, our public hospital outpatient system is incredibly overstretched. Some of the waiting times for urology, for example, are over 12 months, so people are being forced to go to see people privately in their private medical rooms and are faced with huge gap costs. In fact, less than 30 per cent of people seeing specialists in my electorate are bulk-billed, and most of them are faced with large gap costs.

I realise that we are in the middle of a pandemic, and the pandemic exacerbates all those health issues. It exacerbates all the social determinants of health—housing, education, work—and it exacerbates the cost for poor people. We have reached a watershed time in Australia. My questions for the minister are: what does the minister plan to do to finally address the rising disparity that exists in terms of health outcomes in our communities? We have a two-tier health system; that is quite obvious. Does the minister concede that the cost of health care is rising on his watch, and when will he finally take steps to address this? Thirdly, will the government finally take heed of our advice and take steps to address the abysmal state of public hospital outpatient services in our country?

There are other issues that need to be addressed as well. The member for Higgins spoke about mental health. There is a real hotchpotch of treatments available. What we need is coordination. We need help and support for those with severe mental illness, with things like housing and education.

Dr GILLESPIE (Lyne) (13:05): Our recent health budget was exceptional. It builds on a whole half decade or more of continual improvement in medical services. Being in the National Party and being from regional Australia, my colleagues and I are taking a particular interest in how the most recent budget is helping rural medical services.

I note that there was a great initiative to take research into the regions. As you know, we are well-known internationally as a centre for drug and other medical trials. There are already some that are doing regional trials, but we're trying to take the trial architecture out into more regional centres, and this initiative will turbocharge it. Being involved in trials has a lot of advantages. It means that patients, even if they're randomised, are getting a closer technical analysis of their response of their therapy. They can be blinded to get a standard form of treatment—and they're never worse off—but they might get the new treatment which, after the trial, might work out to be much better. If it's all based in metropolitan centres, it means that regional Australia misses out. I would like to know from the minister: when will the initiatives that have been announced, including those in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, come to fruition? I understand that $125 million has been allocated to them.

In the area that I am responsible for, the Lyne electorate, we have two major hospitals—one inside the border and one outside, John Hunter. They are very keen to take clinical trials out to the regions. The University of Newcastle and the Hunter Medical Research Institute are primed and ready to go. At Port Macquarie Base Hospital, we have an existing clinical trials network that have done trials since I started practising there in the early nineties, but they have the capacity to deliver so much more. New South Wales Health has recently announced that the Manning Base Hospital will be upgraded back to its full status as a base hospital. These are just three of the places in New South Wales that could be a portal to more trials in regional Australia. I'm sure there is more information that the minister would have at his fingertips to let us know about that in Queensland and in Victoria.

The other thing that has troubled all health administrations is the metrocentric maldistribution of the medical workforce. It's a phenomenon in all the professions, not just medicine, but it's most acute and most obvious there. Pharmacists have that problem. Physios have that problem. Nursing has that problem. Getting health professionals into regional Australia is hard. As I said, other professions like engineers and accountants have trouble too, but when it's health care it's acute. I would also like further details on the great announcement to expand the Rural Health Multidisciplinary Training Program. For 20 years it has funded 16 university departments of rural health and facilitated medical students doing at least a year of their undergraduate training in these areas, and, due to recent announcements, they will be able to do the whole four or five years, end to end, in regional centres. It's also benefited nursing and allied health training, because they've had a chance to do regional training. We know that if people train in the regions, they're much more likely to have their eyes opened to the wonders of living in regional Australia and to come back there in clinical practice.

The other thing I would like to highlight is that Medicare and access to medicines have been guaranteed. Other people may have highlighted the telehealth initiative. It has just been a godsend for regional Australia, and I would appreciate any further details on that.

So it's been a great budget for health in general but regional health, in particular, has really got a turbocharge behind it with these extra funds. Any further information from the minister would be much appreciated.

Ms MURPHY (Dunkley) (13:09): I have three matters that I wish to ask the minister questions about today. Minister, in my electorate of Dunkley, we are honoured to have Dr John Clements as a resident in Mount Eliza. In January this year, he was awarded the Member of the Order of Australia for significant service to international public health through immunisation programs. I don't have time to read out his entire CV, but he is a public health physician and epidemiologist with expertise in vaccination and immunisation who has worked for the WHO, UNICEF and the World Bank and was part of the global infant and childhood immunisation leadership team at the WHO. He has worked in more than 100 countries and is an associate professor at University of Melbourne and an adjunct associate professor at Monash University.

Dr Clements contacted me in July this year because he had had no success offering his services as a volunteer to the Chief Medical Officer, the Department of Health or your office, Minister, with his wealth of experience. I have followed up, Minister, with your office, as has Dr Clements, a number of times and that offer of assistance hasn't been taken up. So, Minister, my question is: given the enthusiasm with which your government has taken up the expertise of people in business on things like the COVID commission, will you take the offer from Dr Clements to provide his extensive expertise in the rollout of immunisation programs as we are move forward to hopefully a world in which we have a vaccine for COVID-19?

My second question for the minister is something again that I have raised both in this parliament and with the minister. I acknowledge that the minister has responded to me in relation to this issue but, nonetheless, it is one that is ongoing. The St Marys and Bellarto Road medical centres in Carrum Downs and Total Care Medical, run by the amazing Doctor Chung in Frankston, are bulk-billing, and they have this issue in common: they are trying to offer that bulk-billing service in low-socioeconomic areas—and I know the minister is familiar with Carrum Downs and Frankston. They say to me that the removal of Medicare incentive item code 10981 has financially impacted their clinics and has disincentivised doctors to choose bulk-billing over private patients. As is the case with all medical practices around Australia, they have experienced both increased costs and increased demand during the COVID period, including, for example, making sure that the clinic is COVID-safe. They are regularly advertising vacant positions across many platforms—social media, formal medical advertising platforms and wherever they can—but are getting little to no response and are essentially finding it impossible to get Australian trained doctors for bulk-billing practices at their practice. They advise me that, being classified as a distribution priority would be of assistance, and they're not classified as such and that affects recruitment, and that they also experience barriers in arranging visa applications from doctors from overseas when they can't fill the positions with local applicants. So my question, Minister, is: what is the government doing to deal with issues of doctor-GP shortages in outer metropolitan areas—which of course aren't the regional and remote areas that, correctly, some focus has been given to, like in my electorate of Dunkley—to ensure that constituents in low-socioeconomic areas have ongoing access to high-quality bulk-billing GP services?

My final issue and question for the minister goes to something that I have written to the minister about, raised in parliament and spoken about publicly. The minister is aware that Faslodex, a drug to extend end of life, in particular, for people with metastatic breast cancer was approved by PBAC in July for listing on the PBS, and it is now approximately five months later and it hasn't been listed. It is a drug that could cost as little as $6.60 a month for women for the last months and years of their life instead of $1,600 a month. So I ask: Minister, when will you apply your promise of listing all PBAC approved drugs on the PBS—no ifs, no buts—to the metastatic breast cancer drug Faslodex?

Mr COULTON (Parkes—Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government) (13:14): In summing up, I'd like to respond to some of the questions raised during this consideration in detail. The member for Cowper asked some questions about health delivery in his area. Quite recently I was privileged to actually be in the member's electorate. I caught up with some of the medical workforce in his area and was able to discuss issues that were of concern to them. Probably a highlight of the visit was the Werin Aboriginal Corporation Medical Clinic. I'm sure the member for Lyne would be familiar with the great work they do. It's a great model of what we're trying to achieve in delivery, a multidisciplinary approach. At Werin they had GPs, allied health workers, community nurses and even a men's shed for mental health activities for men in the region. What the member for Cowper knows is that it's going to need a holistic approach to be able to address the shortfalls we have, looking at all the resources we actually have on the ground now, whether they are funded through the federal government or the state government, but also breaking down some of those silos so we can have a more collaborative approach.

I was also pleased to hear a question from the member for Bass. Just before the pandemic hit last year I managed to spend some time in her electorate. I actually spoke to the GPs at Lilydale just out of Launceston about some of the concerns they have. In response to the member for Bass, I have been speaking with the Rural Health Commissioner and looking at some models that would be relevant to workforce delivery in Tasmania—once again, making the best use of the resources we have.

Listening to the question from the member for Lyne about clinical trials in regional areas, it really ties in with what we're trying to do. One of the issues around rural workforce is actually making it an attractive option to work in those areas. One of the ways of doing that is to enable rural practitioners to undertake real research and trials, so not only do the people of the regions get the benefits of experiencing some of those life-saving trials first up, as would be their entitlement, but also it creates a highly motivated and professional health workforce, either doctors or allied health, to undertake research as another added part of the job that they are doing.

I believe the issue with rural workforce and rural delivery is to change the stick approach to the carrot. We need to change the environment from the first days of medical school at university, the training approach right through to keeping the training opportunities in the regional areas. Other life experiences that the medical workforce encounter sometimes clash with their ability to relocate into regional areas. Students will be starting to enrol in the Murray-Darling Medical Schools Network early in the new year. We are changing the culture so that the rural workforce is a pathway that people want to take.

I believe regional Australia has a very bright future. COVID has put the spotlight on regional Australia as a land of opportunity. If we're going to reach our full potential we need to make sure that those services are on hand for the people who want to move to regional Australia. Through COVID and since, I've spoken with the rural round table and all the health peak bodies that go into regional areas. I'm working with them and taking their advice to keep promoting the rural workforce and moving it forward.

Ms COLLINS (Franklin) (13:20): I have quite a few more questions for the minister, but, before I go into those, whilst I appreciate that the minister has answered some of the questions raised by his side of the House, I note that the members for Kingston, Cooper, Dobell, Macarthur and Dunkley, on this side of the chamber, have all raised legitimate questions in relation to what we've seen—or the lack thereof—in this budget from the government, and I hope that the Minister for Health, who is still at the table, in his last five minutes actually does try to address some of these really serious questions. We have taken a lot of time to be in here today. The fact that the minister who spoke previously chose to just address his own side's questions is, I think, concerning.
Mr Coulton: Probably because you don't ask questions about rural—

Ms COLLINS: We did actually. That is not true. We raised things about regional health care and about regional mental health services, so that is just not true. I find it really quite appalling that you would respond in that way. I am genuinely asking the Minister for Health to respond to some very serious questions from this side of the House.

The issues I now want to raise with the Minister for Health are in relation to aged care—I'm sure he won't be surprised—and the length of time that it has taken to respond on two concerning issues. One is workforce and having a workforce fit for purpose for aged care, particularly given the fact that our workforce did such a tremendous job during the pandemic. They were on the front line, particularly in residential and home care—a lot of carers, nurses and allied health staff. We had Professor Pollaers's report A matter of care. The professor has raised concerns that the government has been very slow to respond on the 14 actions that he has called on the government to take. I note that the government does have the workforce task force up and running, and I'm pleased to see that, but my question to the government is: why has this taken so long? It has been two years.
